H0.text: They reproduce by mitosis, a characteristic shared by both euglena and amoeba.

H1.text: They eat by phagocytosis is a characteristic that a euglena shares with an amoeba.

H2.text: They respond to light stimuli is a characteristic that euglena shares with an amoeba.

H3.text: They move by changing shape is a characteristic that a euglena shares with an amoeba.

A4.text: Euglena reproduce asexually through binary fission, a form of cell division. Reproduction begins with the mitosis of the cell nucleus, followed by the division of the cell itself.

A5.text: When feeding as a heterotroph, Euglena takes in nutrients by osmotrophy, and can survive without light on a diet of organic matter, such as beef extract, peptone, acetate, ethanol or carbohydrates.
